numbered_ace_sentences: 1. The comment describes a graph about university acceptance rates.
2. The graph compares non-legacy applicants and legacy applicants.
3. The graph groups applicants by income percentile.
4. For non-legacy applicants from the 10th percentile to the 65th percentile, the acceptance rate is 2 times higher than for non-legacy applicants from the 65th percentile to the 90th percentile.
5. For non-legacy applicants, the acceptance rate decreases from the 65th percentile to the 90th percentile.
6. This decrease suggests that richer non-legacy students are disadvantaged in college acceptance.
7. This disadvantage holds even if the test scores are the same.
8. For non-legacy applicants from the 90th percentile to the 99th percentile, the acceptance rate increases significantly.
9. At the 99th percentile, the non-legacy acceptance rate is about 2.5 times higher.
10. For legacy applicants, the average admissions rate on the poor side begins at 2.5 times.
11. For legacy applicants, the chance of acceptance increases after the 50th percentile.
12. For legacy applicants, the chance of acceptance increases from 3 times to 3.5 times after the 50th percentile.
13. For legacy applicants, the graph shows a large increase at the 99th percentile.
14. At the 99th percentile, the legacy likelihood of admission reaches 7 times.
15. The author wonders why the two lines go in opposite directions after the 50th income percentile.
16. The author asks why legacy applicants have an advantage after the 50th percentile.
17. The author asks why non-legacy applicants have a disadvantage after the 50th percentile.
18. The author asks whether colleges have tried to change this discriminatory system since 2015.
19. The author wonders whether families in the 99th percentile are admitted because these families can provide funding to the school.
20. The author will apply to universities.
21. The author thinks that legacy status affects admissions for some schools.
22. The author thinks that the income of the parents affects admissions.
23. The author asks whether a person is disadvantaged in acceptance to some of the most prestigious universities in the United States.
